newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan firms' 96/97 profits seen up--research body.
newsitem.headline: Japan firms' 96/97 profits seen up--research body.

text.p: Kankaku Research Institute Inc said on Monday in a revision of its forecast of major Japanese companies' earnings that it expected their current profits this business year to next March 31 to rise 6.8 percent from the year before.
It said the companies' current profits were expected to rise a further 7.9 percent in the 1997/98 business year.
The survey by the institute, an affiliate of Kankaku Securities Co Ltd, covered 304 firms listed on the first section of the Tokyo Stock Exchange.
The institute had said in June that major companies' current profits would rise 5.2 percent year-on-year in 1996/97 and by 8.4 percent in 1997/98.
The upward revision in its profit forecast for 1996/97 is due to the weaker trend in the yen and robust demand for office automation equipment, it said.
The lowered profit forecast for 1997/98 is because of the upward revision in its 1996/97 profit forecast, it said.
Kankaku Research issues its corporate earnings forecasts four times a year.
Current profit is pre-tax but includes gains and losses made on securities investments and other non-operating activities.
